articles.headline: Some Cities Are Spared the Slide in Housing
articles.snippet: The real estate market these days is a tale of two Americas, and one of them is not doing too badly.
articles.abstract: The real estate market these days is a tale of two Americas, and one of them is not doing too badly.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.  The real estate market these days is a tale of two Americas, and one of them is not doing too badly.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: Gunman Slays 6 at N. Illinois University
articles.snippet: Friday’s classes were canceled at Northern Illinois University after a gunman went into a lecture hall on Thursday and killed six students and himself. Fifteen other students were wounded.
articles.abstract: Friday’s classes were canceled at Northern Illinois University after a gunman went into a lecture hall on Thursday and killed six students and himself. Fifteen other students were wounded.
articles.lead_paragraph: DeKALB, Ill.  With minutes left in a class in ocean sciences at Northern Illinois University on Thursday afternoon, a tall skinny man dressed all in black stepped out from behind a curtain on the stage of the lecture hall, said nothing, and opened fire with a shotgun, the authorities and witnesses said.
articles.byline: By Susan Saulny and Monica Davey

articles.headline: Black Leader, a Clinton Ally, Tilts to Obama
articles.snippet: Representative John Lewis said he planned to cast his vote as a superdelegate for Barack Obama in hopes of preventing a fight at the Democratic convention.
articles.abstract: Representative John Lewis said he planned to cast his vote as a superdelegate for Barack Obama in hopes of preventing a fight at the Democratic convention.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE  Representative John Lewis, an elder statesman from the civil rights era and one of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s most prominent black supporters, said Thursday night that he planned to cast his vote as a superdelegate for Senator Barack Obama in hopes of preventing a fight at the Democratic convention.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Tax Break Helps a Crusader for Deficit Discipline
articles.snippet: Can the co-founder of the Blackstone Group emerge as a credible voice in favor of fiscal constraint in Washington?
articles.abstract: Can the co-founder of the Blackstone Group emerge as a credible voice in favor of fiscal constraint in Washington?
articles.lead_paragraph: “Where is it ordained that private equity pays only a 15 percent tax?”

articles.headline: Top Officials See Bleaker Outlook for the Economy
articles.snippet: Both Ben S. Bernanke and Henry M. Paulson Jr. said they were scaling back their more optimistic forecasts.
articles.abstract: Both Ben S. Bernanke and Henry M. Paulson Jr. said they were scaling back their more optimistic forecasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With the credit markets once again deteriorating, the nation’s two top economic policy makers acknowledged Thursday that the outlook for the economy had worsened, as both came under criticism for being overtaken by events and failing to act boldly enough.

articles.headline: Signs in Kenya of a Land Redrawn by Ethnicity
articles.snippet: After a wave of ethnic violence, Kenya has been in the process of segregating itself.
articles.abstract: After a wave of ethnic violence, Kenya has been in the process of segregating itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTHAYA, Kenya  Sarah Wangoi has spent her entire life  all 70 years of it  in the Rift Valley. But last month, she was chased off her farm by a mob that called her a foreigner. She now sleeps on the cold floor of a stranger’s house, seeking refuge in an area of Kenya where her ethnic group, the Kikuyu, is strong. It is, supposedly, her homeland.

articles.headline: The Times to Cut 100 News Jobs
articles.snippet: After years of resisting the newsroom cuts that have hit most of the industry, The New York Times will bow to growing financial strain, the executive editor said Thursday.
articles.abstract: After years of resisting the newsroom cuts that have hit most of the industry, The New York Times will bow to growing financial strain, the executive editor said Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of resisting the newsroom cuts that have hit most of the industry, The New York Times will bow to growing financial strain and eliminate about 100 newsroom jobs this year, the executive editor said Thursday.

articles.headline: Municipalities Feel Pinch as Another Debt Market Falters
articles.snippet: Alarmed by the running turmoil in the debt markets, investors have refused to buy certain securities that not long ago many regarded as equivalent to cash.
articles.abstract: Alarmed by the running turmoil in the debt markets, investors have refused to buy certain securities that not long ago many regarded as equivalent to cash.
articles.lead_paragraph: The credit crisis paining Wall Street is reaching out across the nation, afflicting municipalities, hospitals and cultural touchstones like the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: When Strains on Military Families Turn Deadly
articles.snippet: An examination of cases of fatal domestic violence and child abuse indicate wartime pressures have complicated the Pentagon’s efforts to change the current system.
articles.abstract: An examination of cases of fatal domestic violence and child abuse indicate wartime pressures have complicated the Pentagon’s efforts to change the current system.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few months after Sgt. William Edwards and his wife, Sgt. Erin Edwards, returned to a Texas Army base from separate missions in Iraq, he assaulted her mercilessly. He struck her, choked her, dragged her over a fence and slammed her into the sidewalk.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez and Deborah Sontag

articles.headline: Make Big Profits Illegally (and Maybe Keep Them, Too)
articles.snippet: In a strange anomaly to American securities laws, it is not clear that someone who illegally obtained insider information has broken the law by trading on that information.
articles.abstract: In a strange anomaly to American securities laws, it is not clear that someone who illegally obtained insider information has broken the law by trading on that information.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is not much doubt that Oleksandr Dorozhko used inside information when he made a killing trading stock options last fall. Nor is there a dispute that he gained the information illegally. His lawyer, arguing before an appeals court this week, spoke of “a high-tech lock pick.”

articles.headline: U.S. to Attempt to Shoot Down Faulty Satellite
articles.snippet: Military officials laid out a plan to shoot down a spy satellite before it tumbles to Earth carrying toxic fuel.
articles.abstract: Military officials laid out a plan to shoot down a spy satellite before it tumbles to Earth carrying toxic fuel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The military will try to shoot down a crippled spy satellite in the next two weeks, senior officials said Thursday. The officials laid out a high-tech plan to intercept the satellite over the Pacific just before it tumbles uncontrollably to Earth carrying toxic fuel.
